definition_brief: Large triangular muscle covering shoulder joint with anterior, middle, and posterior parts responsible for shoulder abduction and rotation
description_full: The deltoid is a thick, powerful, triangular muscle that forms the rounded contour of the shoulder. It consists of three parts: anterior (clavicular), middle (acromial), and posterior (spinal). The muscle wraps around the shoulder joint like a half cone, with converging fibers inserting on the deltoid tuberosity of the humerus. It is the prime mover for shoulder abduction.
clinical_significance: **Deltoid paralysis** from axillary nerve injury causes loss of shoulder abduction and rounded shoulder contour. **Intramuscular injections** are commonly administered into the middle deltoid. **Deltoid atrophy** indicates chronic denervation or disuse. **Strain or tears** occur in athletes. The muscle is split in **deltopectoral surgical approach**. **Reverse shoulder arthroplasty** relies heavily on deltoid function.
origin: Lateral third of clavicle (anterior), acromion (middle), spine of scapula (posterior)
insertion: Deltoid tuberosity of humerus
action: Anterior: flexion, medial rotation; Middle: abduction (15-90°); Posterior: extension, lateral rotation; All parts: stabilize glenohumeral joint
blood_supply: Thoracoacromial artery (anterior), posterior humeral circumflex artery (middle and posterior)

definition_brief: Rotator cuff muscle initiating shoulder abduction and stabilizing humeral head in glenoid cavity
description_full: The supraspinatus is one of four rotator cuff muscles. It occupies the supraspinous fossa of the scapula and passes laterally beneath the acromion and coracoacromial ligament to insert on the superior facet of the greater tubercle. The muscle initiates the first 15 degrees of shoulder abduction and works synergistically with the deltoid throughout the full range of abduction.
clinical_significance: **Supraspinatus tendinopathy** is the most common rotator cuff pathology, causing painful arc syndrome. **Rotator cuff tears** most frequently involve supraspinatus. **Impingement syndrome** compresses the tendon between acromion and humeral head. **Calcific tendinitis** commonly affects this muscle. **Atrophy** visible in supraspinous fossa indicates chronic tear. **Jobe test** specifically assesses supraspinatus function.
origin: Supraspinous fossa of scapula
insertion: Superior facet of greater tubercle of humerus, glenohumeral joint capsule
action: Initiates abduction (0-15°), stabilizes humeral head in glenoid cavity, assists deltoid in abduction

definition_brief: Rotator cuff muscle producing lateral rotation and dynamic stabilization of glenohumeral joint
description_full: The infraspinatus is a thick triangular muscle occupying the infraspinous fossa of the scapula. It is partially covered by the trapezius and deltoid. The muscle converges laterally to pass beneath the acromion and insert on the middle facet of the greater tubercle. It is the primary lateral rotator of the shoulder and an important dynamic stabilizer of the glenohumeral joint.
clinical_significance: **Infraspinatus tears** are the second most common rotator cuff injury after supraspinatus. **Quadrilateral space syndrome** can compress the posterior humeral circumflex artery, causing muscle ischemia and atrophy. **Suprascapular nerve entrapment** at spinoglenoid notch specifically affects infraspinatus. **Infraspinatus atrophy** creates visible hollow in infraspinous fossa. **External rotation lag sign** indicates tear.
origin: Infraspinous fossa of scapula
insertion: Middle facet of greater tubercle of humerus, glenohumeral joint capsule
action: Lateral rotation of arm, stabilization of humeral head, assists in extension and horizontal abduction

definition_brief: Small rotator cuff muscle producing lateral rotation and inferior stabilization of humeral head
description_full: The teres minor is a narrow, elongated muscle of the rotator cuff. It lies inferior to infraspinatus along the lateral border of the scapula and inserts on the inferior facet of the greater tubercle. It works synergistically with infraspinatus in lateral rotation and helps prevent inferior displacement of the humeral head during arm abduction.
clinical_significance: **Teres minor tears** are rare compared to other rotator cuff muscles due to its protected position. **Quadrilateral space syndrome** can affect both the axillary nerve (which innervates teres minor) and posterior humeral circumflex artery. **Hornblower's sign** (inability to laterally rotate at 90° abduction) may indicate teres minor/infraspinatus dysfunction. The muscle is relatively **resistant to impingement**.
origin: Upper two-thirds of lateral border of scapula
insertion: Inferior facet of greater tubercle of humerus, glenohumeral joint capsule
action: Lateral rotation, adduction, stabilization of humeral head (particularly inferior stability)
blood_supply: Circumflex scapular artery, posterior humeral circumflex artery

definition_brief: Largest rotator cuff muscle on subscapular fossa producing medial rotation and anterior stabilization
description_full: The subscapularis is a large, thick triangular muscle that fills the subscapular fossa on the anterior surface of the scapula. It is the only rotator cuff muscle on the anterior aspect of the scapula. The muscle passes laterally to insert on the lesser tubercle of the humerus. It is the primary medial rotator of the shoulder and prevents anterior dislocation of the humeral head.
clinical_significance: **Subscapularis tears** are often missed but account for ~30% of rotator cuff pathology. **Lift-off test** and **belly-press test** assess subscapularis integrity. Tears predispose to **anterior shoulder instability**. **Subcoracoid impingement** can damage the superior subscapularis. The muscle is at risk during **anterior shoulder surgery**. **Isolated subscapularis tears** often result from forced external rotation.
origin: Subscapular fossa of scapula
insertion: Lesser tubercle of humerus, anterior glenohumeral joint capsule
action: Medial rotation, adduction, anterior stabilization of humeral head, depression of humeral head
innervation: Upper and lower subscapular nerves (C5, C6, C7)

definition_brief: Thick muscle producing adduction, medial rotation, and extension of arm at shoulder
description_full: The teres major is a thick, flattened muscle extending from the inferior angle of the scapula to the medial lip of the intertubercular groove of the humerus. It lies inferior to teres minor and forms the inferior border of both the quadrangular and triangular spaces. The muscle works synergistically with latissimus dorsi and is sometimes called the 'lat's little helper.'
clinical_significance: **Teres major tears** are uncommon but occur in athletes performing overhead activities. The muscle forms boundaries of **quadrangular space** (containing axillary nerve and posterior humeral circumflex vessels) and **triangular space** (containing circumflex scapular vessels). **Teres major transfer** is used in some shoulder reconstruction procedures. **Hypertrophy** is common in climbers and swimmers.
origin: Posterior surface of inferior angle of scapula
insertion: Medial lip of intertubercular groove of humerus
action: Adduction, medial rotation, extension of arm

definition_brief: Large fan-shaped chest muscle producing adduction, medial rotation, and flexion of arm
description_full: The pectoralis major is a thick, fan-shaped muscle forming the anterior wall of the axilla and the bulk of the male chest. It consists of clavicular and sternocostal heads. The muscle fibers converge laterally to insert on the lateral lip of the intertubercular groove, with the tendon twisting so that inferior fibers insert superiorly. The clavicular and sternocostal portions can act independently.
clinical_significance: **Pectoralis major rupture** occurs in weightlifters during bench press, requiring surgical repair. **Poland syndrome** involves congenital absence or hypoplasia. **Pectoralis major myocutaneous flap** is used in breast reconstruction. The muscle forms the **anterior axillary fold**. **Tightness** contributes to rounded shoulder posture. The **clavipectoral fascia** separates it from deeper structures.
origin: Clavicular head: anterior surface of medial half of clavicle; Sternocostal head: anterior sternum, costal cartilages 1-6, external oblique aponeurosis
insertion: Lateral lip of intertubercular groove of humerus
action: Adduction, medial rotation; Clavicular head: flexion; Sternocostal head: extension from flexed position; Both: horizontal adduction
blood_supply: Pectoral branch of thoracoacromial artery, lateral thoracic artery, perforating branches of internal thoracic artery

definition_brief: Broad, flat back muscle producing extension, adduction, and medial rotation of arm
description_full: The latissimus dorsi is a large, flat, triangular muscle covering the lumbar region and lower thorax. It is the widest muscle of the back (latissimus = widest). The muscle converges to a narrow tendon that twists before inserting in the intertubercular groove. It forms the posterior axillary fold and can be palpated during pull-ups or chin-ups.
clinical_significance: **Latissimus dorsi flap** is widely used in breast reconstruction and other plastic surgery procedures. **Latissimus dorsi transfer** can restore elbow flexion in brachial plexus injuries. **Tear or strain** occurs in athletes, particularly baseball pitchers. The muscle is involved in **cough mechanics** and can be recruited as an **accessory muscle of respiration**. **Myofascial pain** commonly affects this muscle.
origin: Spinous processes T7-L5, posterior sacrum, iliac crest, inferior 3-4 ribs, inferior angle of scapula
insertion: Floor of intertubercular groove of humerus
action: Extension, adduction, medial rotation of arm; depression of shoulder girdle; assists in forced expiration and coughing
blood_supply: Thoracodorsal artery (primary), circumflex scapular artery, posterior intercostal arteries, lumbar arteries

definition_brief: Two-headed muscle of anterior arm producing powerful supination and elbow flexion
description_full: The biceps brachii has two heads: long and short. The long head originates from the supraglenoid tubercle and passes through the intertubercular groove. The short head arises from the coracoid process. Both heads merge into a single muscle belly that inserts via a thick tendon onto the radial tuberosity. A second insertion, the bicipital aponeurosis, fans out medially into the forearm fascia.
clinical_significance: **Proximal biceps tendinopathy** and **tendon rupture** cause anterior shoulder pain and characteristic 'Popeye deformity.' **Distal biceps rupture** impairs supination strength more than flexion. **SLAP lesions** involve the superior labrum and long head anchor. **Bicipital tendinitis** causes tenderness in the intertubercular groove. **Hook test** assesses distal biceps integrity. The muscle is easily palpable and used for **blood pressure measurement**.
origin: Long head: supraglenoid tubercle of scapula; Short head: coracoid process of scapula
insertion: Radial tuberosity, bicipital aponeurosis into forearm fascia
action: Powerful supination of forearm, flexion of elbow, weak flexion of shoulder (long head), weak adduction (short head)

definition_brief: Three-headed muscle of posterior arm serving as primary elbow extensor
description_full: The triceps brachii has three heads: long, lateral, and medial. The long head originates from the infraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and is the only head crossing the shoulder joint. The lateral and medial heads arise from the posterior humerus. All three heads converge into a common tendon inserting on the olecranon. The muscle is the sole occupant of the posterior compartment of the arm.
clinical_significance: **Triceps tendon rupture** is less common than biceps rupture but severely impairs extension. **Radial nerve palsy** causes triceps weakness with wrist drop. **Triceps tendinopathy** occurs in throwing athletes and weightlifters. **Olecranon bursitis** can develop from repetitive triceps contraction. The muscle is used for **intramuscular injections**. **Triceps reflex** (C6-C8) is important in neurological examination.
origin: Long head: infraglenoid tubercle of scapula; Lateral head: posterior humerus superior to radial groove; Medial head: posterior humerus inferior to radial groove
insertion: Olecranon of ulna, forearm fascia
action: Extension of elbow (all heads), extension and adduction of shoulder (long head only), stabilization of elbow joint
blood_supply: Deep brachial artery (profunda brachii), superior and inferior ulnar collateral arteries

definition_brief: Powerful elbow flexor deep to biceps, active in all positions of forearm rotation
description_full: The brachialis is a fusiform muscle lying deep to the biceps brachii on the anterior distal humerus. It originates broadly from the anterior surface of the distal half of the humerus and inserts on the coronoid process and tuberosity of the ulna. Unlike biceps, it acts purely on the elbow joint and is equally effective in all positions of forearm rotation, making it the 'workhorse' of elbow flexion.
clinical_significance: **Brachialis injury** occurs in rock climbers and causes anterior elbow pain. **Myositis ossificans** can develop after elbow trauma, particularly in the brachialis. The muscle can be affected in **anterior interosseous syndrome**. **Volkmann's ischemic contracture** involves brachialis along with other forearm flexors. The muscle is a key landmark in **anterior surgical approaches** to the humerus.
origin: Anterior surface of distal half of humerus, medial and lateral intermuscular septa
insertion: Coronoid process and tuberosity of ulna
action: Flexion of elbow in all positions of forearm rotation
innervation: Musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6), small contribution from radial nerve to lateral part
blood_supply: Brachial artery (muscular branches), radial recurrent artery

definition_brief: Small muscle producing weak flexion and adduction of arm, serving as key anatomical landmark
description_full: The coracobrachialis is a small, elongated muscle in the anterior arm arising from the coracoid process alongside the short head of biceps. It inserts on the medial mid-shaft of the humerus. Though weak in action, it serves as an important anatomical landmark: the musculocutaneous nerve pierces through it, and it helps define the axilla boundaries.
clinical_significance: The **musculocutaneous nerve** consistently pierces the coracobrachialis, making it vulnerable during surgery or trauma. **Anomalous muscle anatomy** can cause nerve entrapment. The muscle is a landmark for **axillary node dissection** and **brachial plexus blocks**. **Tears** are rare but can occur with anterior shoulder dislocation. The muscle helps define the **medial boundary of the bicipital compartment**.
origin: Tip of coracoid process of scapula (common tendon with short head of biceps)
insertion: Middle third of medial surface of humerus
action: Weak flexion and adduction of arm at shoulder, assists in stabilization of humeral head
innervation: Musculocutaneous nerve (C5, C6, C7) - nerve pierces the muscle belly

definition_brief: Superficial forearm muscle producing pronation and weak elbow flexion
description_full: The pronator teres has two heads: humeral (larger) from the medial epicondyle and ulnar from the coronoid process. The median nerve passes between these heads. The muscle crosses the forearm obliquely to insert on the lateral mid-shaft of the radius. It is the most superficial muscle of the flexor-pronator group and forms the medial border of the cubital fossa.
clinical_significance: **Pronator syndrome** involves median nerve compression between the two heads, causing forearm pain and hand paresthesias. **Medial epicondylitis** affects the pronator origin. The muscle is a key landmark in **anterior forearm approaches**. **Hypertrophy** occurs in activities requiring repetitive pronation. **Pronator teres tendon transfer** can restore finger extension in radial nerve palsy.
origin: Humeral head: medial epicondyle of humerus (common flexor origin), medial supracondylar ridge; Ulnar head: coronoid process of ulna
insertion: Middle of lateral surface of radius (pronator tuberosity)
action: Pronation of forearm, weak flexion of elbow

definition_brief: Superficial forearm flexor producing wrist flexion and radial deviation
description_full: The flexor carpi radialis is a superficial muscle in the anterior forearm arising from the medial epicondyle. Its long tendon passes through a separate compartment in the flexor retinaculum to insert on the bases of the second and third metacarpals. The tendon is easily palpable at the wrist and commonly used for assessing radial pulse.
clinical_significance: **FCR tendinitis** causes radial-sided wrist pain. The tendon is a common **autograft source** for ligament reconstruction. **Intersection syndrome** involves tenosynovitis where APL/EPB cross FCR. The **radial artery pulse** is palpated lateral to FCR tendon. **Rupture** is rare but can occur with degenerative changes. The muscle is involved in **medial epicondylitis**.
origin: Medial epicondyle of humerus (common flexor origin)
insertion: Bases of 2nd and 3rd metacarpal bones (palmar surface)
action: Flexion of wrist, radial deviation (abduction) of wrist, weak pronation, weak elbow flexion

definition_brief: Most medial superficial forearm flexor producing wrist flexion and ulnar deviation
description_full: The flexor carpi ulnaris has two heads: humeral (from medial epicondyle) and ulnar (from olecranon and posterior ulna). The ulnar nerve and artery pass beneath the tendinous arch between these heads. The muscle forms the medial border of the anterior forearm and inserts on the pisiform, hook of hamate, and fifth metacarpal base via the pisohamate and pisometacarpal ligaments.
clinical_significance: **FCU tendinitis** causes ulnar-sided wrist pain. **Ulnar nerve compression** can occur between the two heads (cubital tunnel). **Pisiform fracture** may involve the FCU insertion. The muscle is a common **tendon transfer** donor in reconstructive surgery. **Ulnar artery palpation** is performed along FCU. **Hypothenar hammer syndrome** affects the ulnar artery as it crosses FCU.
origin: Humeral head: medial epicondyle of humerus; Ulnar head: medial olecranon, posterior border of ulna
insertion: Pisiform bone, hook of hamate, base of 5th metacarpal (via pisohamate and pisometacarpal ligaments)
action: Flexion of wrist, ulnar deviation (adduction) of wrist, weak elbow flexion
blood_supply: Ulnar artery, posterior ulnar recurrent artery

definition_brief: Vestigial superficial forearm flexor with long tendon inserting into palmar aponeurosis
description_full: The palmaris longus is a slender, superficial muscle with a short belly and long tendon. It arises from the medial epicondyle and inserts into the palmar aponeurosis. The muscle is absent in ~15% of people (unilaterally or bilaterally) without functional deficit. Its prominent tendon is easily palpable at the wrist when flexing against resistance.
clinical_significance: The palmaris longus is the **most common tendon graft donor** for reconstructive surgery due to its expendability. **Congenital absence** occurs in ~15% of population. The tendon is easily identified for **clinical examination** and **surgical landmarks**. **Palmaris longus transfer** can augment thumb opposition. **Reversed palmaris longus flap** is used in hand reconstruction.
origin: Medial epicondyle of humerus (common flexor origin)
insertion: Flexor retinaculum, palmar aponeurosis
action: Weak wrist flexion, tenses palmar aponeurosis

definition_brief: Intermediate layer forearm muscle producing flexion at PIP joints of digits 2-5
description_full: The flexor digitorum superficialis has two heads: humeroulnar (medial epicondyle, ulnar collateral ligament, coronoid process) and radial (anterior radius). It forms the intermediate layer of anterior forearm flexors. Four tendons pass through the carpal tunnel and split to insert on the sides of the middle phalanges of digits 2-5, allowing FDP tendons to pass through to reach the distal phalanges.
clinical_significance: **FDS testing** involves isolated PIP flexion while holding other fingers extended. **Trigger finger** commonly involves FDS tendons at A1 pulley. **Camper's chiasm** is where FDS tendons split to allow FDP passage. **Jersey finger** may involve both FDS and FDP. **FDS transfer** is used in tendon reconstruction. The muscle contributes to **carpal tunnel syndrome** when hypertrophied.
origin: Humeroulnar head: medial epicondyle, ulnar collateral ligament, coronoid process; Radial head: anterior oblique line of radius
insertion: Sides of middle phalanges of digits 2-5
action: Flexion of PIP joints of digits 2-5, assists in MCP flexion and wrist flexion
blood_supply: Median artery, ulnar artery, radial artery

definition_brief: Deep forearm flexor producing DIP flexion of digits 2-5, the only muscle capable of this action
description_full: The flexor digitorum profundus arises from the anterior and medial surfaces of the proximal three-quarters of the ulna and adjacent interosseous membrane. It forms four tendons that pass through the carpal tunnel deep to FDS. Each tendon passes through the split in the corresponding FDS tendon to insert on the base of the distal phalanx. FDP is the only muscle capable of flexing the DIP joint.
clinical_significance: **Jersey finger** (FDP avulsion) occurs when actively flexing finger is forcefully extended. **Isolated DIP flexion** tests FDP integrity. The **medial portion** (digits 4-5) is innervated by ulnar nerve while **lateral portion** (digits 2-3) is innervated by anterior interosseous nerve (median). **Quadrigia effect** occurs when repair of one tendon restricts motion of others. **FDP testing** is critical in hand examination.
origin: Anterior and medial surfaces of proximal 3/4 of ulna, interosseous membrane, coronoid process
insertion: Palmar surfaces of bases of distal phalanges of digits 2-5
action: Flexion of DIP joints of digits 2-5, assists in PIP and MCP flexion, assists in wrist flexion
innervation: Lateral part (index and middle): anterior interosseous nerve (median, C8, T1); Medial part (ring and little): ulnar nerve (C8, T1)

definition_brief: Deep forearm muscle providing powerful flexion of thumb IP joint
description_full: The flexor pollicis longus arises from the anterior surface of the radius and adjacent interosseous membrane. Its tendon passes through the carpal tunnel in its own synovial sheath, lateral to the other flexor tendons, then through the flexor sheath of the thumb to insert on the palmar surface of the distal phalanx. It is the only muscle capable of flexing the thumb IP joint.
clinical_significance: **FPL testing** involves isolated IP flexion of thumb. **Anterior interosseous syndrome** causes isolated FPL weakness with inability to make an 'OK' sign. **Rupture** can occur from sharp trauma or chronic attrition over bony spurs. **FPL tenosynovitis** causes thumb pain and swelling. **Trigger thumb** may involve FPL. The muscle is critical for **precision pinch** and **power grip**.
origin: Anterior surface of radius (middle half), adjacent interosseous membrane, occasionally medial epicondyle
insertion: Palmar surface of base of distal phalanx of thumb
action: Flexion of IP joint of thumb, assists in flexion of MCP and CMC joints of thumb
innervation: Anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve, C7, C8)

definition_brief: Deep square muscle of distal forearm providing primary pronation force
description_full: The pronator quadratus is a flat, quadrilateral muscle located in the deepest layer of the anterior forearm, spanning transversely between the distal radius and ulna. It is the deepest muscle in the forearm and the primary pronator, active in all pronation movements regardless of elbow position, unlike pronator teres which is more effective with the elbow flexed.
clinical_significance: **Pronator quadratus** is the **primary pronator** and maintains its function even when pronator teres is paralyzed. **Fractures of the distal radius** can disrupt the muscle. The **pronator quadratus fat plane** displacement on lateral radiographs indicates distal radius fracture. **Surgical exposure** requires careful dissection. The muscle helps maintain **radioulnar stability**.
origin: Anterior surface of distal quarter of ulna
insertion: Anterior surface of distal quarter of radius
action: Primary pronation of forearm, binds radius and ulna together
innervation: Anterior interosseous nerve (branch of median nerve, C7, C8)

definition_brief: Superficial lateral forearm muscle producing elbow flexion and returning forearm to neutral from pronation/supination
description_full: The brachioradialis is a fusiform muscle forming the lateral border of the cubital fossa. Despite being anatomically in the posterior (extensor) compartment, it functions as a flexor. It arises from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus and inserts on the radial styloid process. The muscle is most effective at flexing the elbow when the forearm is in mid-position (neutral).
clinical_significance: **Brachioradialis reflex** (C5, C6) is tested by tapping the tendon proximal to the radial styloid. **Radial nerve palsy** can weaken brachioradialis while preserving biceps and brachialis (median nerve innervated). **Lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve** emerges adjacent to the muscle. The muscle is a landmark for **radial artery palpation**. **Hypertrophy** occurs in climbers.
origin: Proximal two-thirds of lateral supracondylar ridge of humerus, lateral intermuscular septum
insertion: Lateral surface of distal radius (just proximal to styloid process)
action: Flexion of elbow (most effective in mid-position), returns forearm to neutral from full pronation or supination

definition_brief: Lateral forearm extensor producing wrist extension and radial deviation
description_full: The extensor carpi radialis longus arises from the lateral supracondylar ridge of the humerus, forming a muscle belly that extends further distally than brachioradialis. Its tendon passes through the second dorsal compartment of the wrist to insert on the base of the second metacarpal. It works synergistically with ECRB to extend the wrist.
clinical_significance: **Lateral epicondylitis** (tennis elbow) frequently affects ECRL along with ECRB. **de Quervain's tenosynovitis** may be confused with ECRL tendinitis. **Intersection syndrome** involves inflammation where APL/EPB cross the ECRL/ECRB tendons. **ECRL transfer** is used in reconstructive procedures. The muscle is critical for **wrist stabilization** during power grip.
origin: Distal third of lateral supracondylar ridge of humerus, lateral intermuscular septum
insertion: Dorsal surface of base of 2nd metacarpal bone
action: Extension of wrist, radial deviation (abduction) of wrist, weak elbow flexion

definition_brief: Lateral forearm extensor inserting on third metacarpal, primary wrist extensor
description_full: The extensor carpi radialis brevis lies deep to ECRL and arises from the lateral epicondyle via the common extensor tendon. Its tendon passes through the second dorsal compartment alongside ECRL to insert on the base of the third metacarpal. ECRB is considered the primary wrist extensor due to its central position.
clinical_significance: **ECRB is the primary structure** affected in lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow), showing degenerative changes at its origin. **Surgical debridement** of ECRB is the primary treatment for chronic tennis elbow. **Intersection syndrome** involves ECRB tendons. **ECRB transfer** to ECRPL can treat radial nerve palsy. The muscle is essential for **wrist extension** during finger flexion.
origin: Lateral epicondyle of humerus (common extensor origin), radial collateral ligament, adjacent fascia
insertion: Dorsal surface of base of 3rd metacarpal bone
action: Extension of wrist, weak radial deviation, assists in elbow flexion
innervation: Deep branch of radial nerve (posterior interosseous nerve, C6, C7)

definition_brief: Primary extensor of fingers 2-5, extending MCP, PIP, and DIP joints
description_full: The extensor digitorum arises from the lateral epicondyle and forms four tendons that pass through the fourth dorsal compartment. On the dorsum of the hand, the tendons are connected by intertendinous connections (juncturae tendinum). Each tendon forms an extensor expansion (hood) over the MCP joint and divides into three slips: central (to middle phalanx) and two lateral (to distal phalanx via terminal tendon).
clinical_significance: **Extensor tendon injuries** are classified by zone (1-8). **Mallet finger** involves zone 1 disruption. **Boutonniere deformity** results from central slip rupture. **Juncturae tendinum** can maintain partial extension even with tendon laceration. **Extensor lag** indicates dysfunction. **Sagittal band rupture** causes subluxation of ED tendons. **Rheumatoid arthritis** commonly affects extensor tendons.
origin: Lateral epicondyle of humerus (common extensor origin)
insertion: Extensor expansion: base of middle phalanx (central slip), base of distal phalanx (terminal tendon) of digits 2-5
action: Extension of MCP joints of digits 2-5, assists in extension of IP joints, assists in wrist extension and abduction of digits
innervation: Posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve, C6, C7, C8)
blood_supply: Posterior interosseous artery, anterior interosseous artery

definition_brief: Medial forearm extensor producing wrist extension and ulnar deviation
description_full: The extensor carpi ulnaris has two heads arising from the lateral epicondyle (humeral head) and posterior ulna (ulnar head). The tendon passes through the sixth dorsal compartment in a groove between the ulnar styloid and head, held by a fibro-osseous tunnel. It inserts on the base of the fifth metacarpal. ECU is a key stabilizer of the distal radioulnar joint.
clinical_significance: **ECU tendinitis and subluxation** are common in racquet sports. **ECU subsheath injury** allows tendon subluxation with forearm supination. **ECU tendon rupture** can occur with forceful wrist extension. The muscle is involved in **triangular fibrocartilage complex** (TFCC) stability. **ECU syndrome** causes ulnar-sided wrist pain. The tendon is palpable over the ulnar head.
origin: Lateral epicondyle of humerus (common extensor origin), posterior border of ulna via common aponeurosis with FCU and anconeus
insertion: Tubercle on medial side of base of 5th metacarpal bone
action: Extension of wrist, ulnar deviation (adduction) of wrist, assists in pronation
innervation: Posterior interosseous nerve (deep branch of radial nerve, C6, C7, C8)
